name: places/ChIJBZ8O2ahYwokROg7CvUHyCQE
adrFormatAddress: 1901 1st Ave., New York, NY 10029, USA

originalText.text: This is the first time I visit the ER for adults, the ER for kids seems a little more cleaner but the adult section is packed. You have to sit right next to people who are coughing all over the place. There is no space between you and other patients. I left 15 of me sitting down and went to a different ER. The place doesn’t look clean to me and to be registered was a huge long list. I have never experienced that before so I was pretty shocked. Even if you have to wait long there is a time to take vitals and it doesn’t usually take that long even if you’re getting registered. When I felt the wind of the cough of the lady next to me I stepped out because I was not even there for a cough and I’m pretty sure I would be leaving with one. They need to do better spacing between patients. Clean the place up and have a different system. On top of that the registration nurse was rude to some people, you can barely hear names being called out because of construction. I would think this would be better after Covid but it doesn’t seem a place I would want to go if I want to feel better. You’ll come out having whatever other people have.

originalText.text:
If you make it through the disastrous emergency room, to the musch more professional treatment, you would be in luck. 25% of the ER staff (nurses, techs, resident doctors, intake receptionists) are great n worthy of accolades.  Sadly, however, the remaining 75% treat poorer patients worse than roaches.

Rudeness, ignoring patient pleas for help, ignoring patients in excessive paid for hours (other than a staffer looking in the room sporadically. Doctors have literally walked away from cordially patients, in pain, simply requesting brief dialog.  Stains on sheets even when patients first put in their room.  Dirt on walls, but most walks are clean.

Excessive wait times in ER.  If the 25% great staff quit, this place will be even worse.  Culture of negligence, racism, etc.  Dont go here, better to die with dignity, and sadly the professionals in surgery wont see you, go elsewhere or die at home with dignity!  Mt Sinai is only about 15% better.

originalText.text: Got here around 10:30pm or a little later ended leaving around 1:50am the nurses that were taking care of everything were ok better compared to other hospitals I've been to here in NYC some of the doctors were also ok the only thing I felted like I wasn't being told everything at times or maybe I was just paranoid that they just wanted to send me home but I dont know but gladly they told me that my blood work was ok and I just have to make some changes in my life.

originalText.text:
The ER receptionist was incredibly rude to a disabled patient who was at the ER with blood clot symptoms.

The receptionist berated the patient for taking 11 minutes to fill out their insurance form (as opposed to the five the receptionist thought it should take). When the patient said they are disabled and going as quickly as they could, the receptionist continued rudely, explaining that ER’s are for emergencies - and made no effort at apology. Perhaps, in this medical professional’s eyes intense chest pain and a referral from Urgent Care don’t warrant an emergency.

There were maybe four or five others waiting in the room, not that it would have been an excuse if the room was packed, but that wasn’t even the case.

The medical field is often a thankless job and it’s definitely a high-stress occupation working in an Emergency Room, however, the complete lack of empathy or professional composure may leave patients highly disappointed when visiting this location.

Unfortunately, it’s one of the most highly rated ERs in the city, which I guess isn’t saying much.

originalText.text: Uncaring staff and incredibly difficult to work with, you have to call to schedule a non-primary care doctor and they put you on hold and frequently hang up on you or transfer you to dead lines.
